Barrault *, M Blanchard, A Derouault, M. Ksibi, M. I. Zaki 1 Laboratoire de Catalyse, URA-CNRS 350, ESIP, 40 avenue Recteur Pineau, 86022 Poitiers Cedex, France Received 21 September 1993, revised 16 February 1994, accepted 3 June 1994 Abstract Cobalt catalysts obtained from the reduction of Co(acac)2 with Al(Et)3 have been studied by infrared spectroscopy (in the selective hydrogenation of multifunctional compounds) These solids prepared in situ were to suspension to a liquid mixture containing solvent and reagent In order to obtain information on the preparation and the composition of the catalyst we carried out an FT-IR characterization using a special device warranting sample manipulation in air-free atmosphere At room temperature there were instantaneous and reductive ligand-exchange between Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 and formation of Coo particles, Coo soluble complexes and Al(Et)2(acac) The multistep process may be initiated through the formation of a donor-acceptor complex ((acac)Co(acac) -> Al(Et)3) The presence of CO in the gas phase (HZ) when heating the reaction mixture up to 180 C enhances the reduction of cobalt and probes Coo in different coordination symmetries Some of the Coo species could be surrounded with cobalt alkoxide species and aluminium acetylacetonate Keywords Acetylacetonate complexes, Cobalt, FT-IR spectroscopy, Reduction, Tnethylalumimum 1. Introduction Ziegler-type cobalt catalysts are highly active and selective m liquid phase polymerization and hydrogenation processes of both industrial and technological importance Oligomenzation of butadiene [ 1 ] , copolymerization of vinyl acetate with acrylonitrile [ 2 ] , and synthesis of alkenes and alcohols via hydrogenation of CO (Fischer-Tropsch) [ 3,4 ] are important examples of such processes, involving * Corresponding author ' On leave from University El Mima, Egypt mnn c In') /QA/-W7 /ln 0) 1994 Flcevier Science B V All rights reserved 290 J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 289-304 cobalt catalysts Moreover during the last decade, the catalysts have been found active m the selective hydrogenation of nitnle [ 5 ] and in the formation of fine chemicals via hydrogenation of a, ssl3-unsaturated carbonyl derivatives [ 6] The catalysts are often obtained from the reaction of cobalt acetylacetonate [Co(acac)2 [7] or Co(acac)3 [8] ]withaluminiumtnalkyl [ Al (R) 31 in an organic solvent Reductive ligand-exchange reactions occur immediately at room temperature, whereby a range of soluble metal complexes (of Co, Al, and possibly CoAl), Co' metal particles and free hydrocarbons may be produced [ 8,9] The nature of these complexes are largely controlled by differences in preparation [ 8,9 ] , vii , the Al/Co ratio, the sequence of reagent mixing, the nature of the alkyl group of Al (R) 3, the initial oxidation state of Co, and the nature of the solvent An additional parameter is high temperature treatment often necessitated by hydrogenation processes [3,4] Many studies, dealing with the catalyst, have been focused on the activity and selectivity as a function of preparation method (e g , [ 2 ] ) In contrast, few studies have tackled the formation and nature of the catalyst active species [ 8 ] . The present investigation aims basically to characterize the chemical reactions occurring from the mixing of solutions of Co(acac)2 and Al(Et)3, and the formation of catalyst, used for the selective hydrogenation of a,/3-unsaturated carbonyl derivatives [ 5,6 ] It implements the potential of F17-IR spectroscopy, in resolving the chemical complexity inherent to the preparation medium[ 8,9 ] This approach has been motivated by previous IR studies of analogous Ziegler-type catalysts [ 10,11 ] Moreover, the investigation adopted recommended techniques and conditions so as to warrant sample manipulation and measurements m air-free atmosphere [ 12 ] 2. Experimental 21 Materials The cobalt acetylacetonate (Co (acac) 2, acac = CSH802; 98 wt%-Co) aluminium tnethyl (Al (Et) 3, Et = C2H5, 93 wt%-Al), acetylacetonate (Al (acac) 3, 98 wt%Al) and isopropoxide (Al (lPr) 3, iPr = C3H70) were Merck products Co (acac) 2 and Al (acac)3 was dried at 10-2 Torr and 55 C for 8 h, prior to application The solvents used were benzene (Bz), (99% Prolabo) for low-temperature handling, and dodecane (Dod ) , (99 % Interchim) for high-temperature treatments Benzene was distilled (under N2) in the presence of sodium metal and benzophenone, according to a standard procedure [ 13 ] 2 2 Co(acac)2 reduction 8 71 g of dried Co (acac) 2 were dissolved in 220 ml of dried benzene at room temperature (RT), under argon atmosphere After cooling down to 6 C, a 5 ml J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 289-304 291 portion of Al (Et)3 (Al /Co=1) was added by means of an air-tight syringe. The colour darkened immediately and a suspension of fine particles was formed A 60 ml portion of dodecane was added and benzene was eliminated by distillation at 60 C under hydrogen A slurry was obtained which was then transferred into an all-Pyrex glass reactor and the temperature was raised slowly up to 180 C under HZ The slurry was maintained at this temperature for 2 h prior to any further change In certain instances, reduction conditions were vaned the Al/Co ratio (0 5-1 5) , the reduction temperature (RT-180 C) and duration (5 mm, 18 h) In order to monitor changes in the nature of the species formed during this preparation, we also studied the adsorption-reduction of carbon monoxide diluted in hydrogen (25-30 vol%) at atmospheric pressure 2 3 Sampling procedures and tools for IR analysis Recommendations and techniques put forward by De Liefde Meyer et al [ 12] for IR sampling under absolute air-free conditions were strictly considered A SPECACIR-cell of 0 025 mm thickness, equipped with KBr windows, was placed inside an evacuable desiccator, together with a small beaker. The desiccator was equipped with two ground onfices terminated with greaseless taps, as well as fittings necessary for connection to a gas/vacuum line The desiccator and the fittings were subjected to three successive cycles of evacuation-Ar flushing Finally, an Arpressure was maintained to avoid readmission of air The test sample was then delivered into the cell by means of a dry, hypodermic syringe. For the sake of cautiousness, the very first drops of the sample were dispensed into the beaker With the help of special tongs, the cell ports were blocked with Ar-flushed Teflon corks Eventually, the cell was transferred, in air, into the sample compartment of the IR spectrophotometer (vide infra), which was continuously being purged with dry NZ 2 4. Infrared spectroscopy IR absorption spectra were taken, over the frequency range from 400 to 4800 cm-', using a N2-purged model lOMX Nicolet FT-spectrophotometer equipped with a data acquisition and handling system All spectra were taken at beam temperature, i e close to RT, and observed frequencies were accurate to within t 2 cm-1 The chemical complexity of test samples was resolved by means of difference spectra These were obtained by absorption subtraction of spectra recorded under identical spectroscopic conditions The subtraction was facilitated by the interfaced data handling system It is worth reporting, that gas phase components in the test samples were undetectable, for the very short optical pathlength of the cell employed (0 025 mm thick) 292 J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 282304 2.5. Gas chromatography Gases formed during the reaction of Co (acac) 2 which Al (Et) 3 were sampled and analyzed with a 3300 Varian gas chromatograph equipped with a 25 m Chrompack ISG capillary column 3. Results and discussion 31 Chemical consequences of mixing Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)3 at room temperature 31 1 As a function of the AUCo ratio Fig 1 compares IR spectra of benzene solutions of Al (Et) 3 and Co (acac) 2 at various Al/Co ratios, namely at Al/Co of 0 5, 1 0 and 1 5. The figure also insets the spectrum taken from Co (acac) 2 solution prior to addition of Al (Et) 3, 1 e , at Al/Co=0 0 The solvent contribution was almost completely eliminated by subtraction Frequencies of characteristic absorptions exhibited by separate solutions of Co (acac)2 and At (Et)3 below 2000 cm-', are summarized m Table 1. The table also summarizes frequencies of absorptions observed at < 2000 cm-' for the reference compounds of Al (acac) 3, Al (Et) 2 (acac) and Al (iPr) 3 Fig 1 shows that the addition of Al (Et) 3 to Co (acac) 2 (A1 /Co = 0.5) induced some detectable changes m the IR spectrum of Co(acac)2 The most important changes, are the emergence of new absorptions at 1533, 1289, 1027, 939, and 490 cm-' Moreover, the absorption at 1401 cm-' splits into two strongly overlapping but weaker absorptions at 1410 and 1391 cm-' On the other hand, some of the initial absorptions, due to Co(acac)2, weaken significantly (e.g , at 1519, 1260, 924 cm -' ) , whereas others undergo slight frequency shifts (e g ,from 1591 to 1596 cm-', from 1196 to 1194 cm-', and from 420 to 425 cm-') and grow stronger In terms of the reference data compiled m Table 1 and other reports [ 15], these changes show that Al (Et) 3 is transformed into Al (acac) 3 species The newly emerging absorptions at 1533, 1289, and 490 cm-' are diagnostic to the formation of Al(acac)3 (Table 1) The 1533 and 1289 cm-' absorptions seem (Fig 1) to be high-frequency modifications of Co(acac)2 absorptions at 1519 (v(CO) + v(C-C) ) and 1260 cm-' ( v(C-C) + v(C-CH3) ) , respectively This implies that acetylacetonate ligands are now coordinated to a stronger Lewis acid centre (Al) than Co [ 16] The emergence of the 490 cm-' absorption indicates stretching vibrations of Al-O bonds [ 8 ] , which can be correlated with the slight high-frequency shift of the 420 cm-' absorption ( v(Co-O) ) to 425 cm-' (out of plane bending of At (acac)3) [8,15] J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 289-304 OZC-C-S-- O -o S06 ~ 6 6 196 886 OZOI LZOI Szb Z6P 06b S DZ6 0911 Y6li- LZZI 09ZI 9611 6151 US l~ 9691 1651 6091 - J 8arrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 289-304 Table 1 Frequency values ( t 2 cm-') of characteristic IR absorptions of the catalyst precursors and some other reference compounds m benzene Co(acac)2 1609 1591 1401 1364 1260 1196 1020 924 420 1519 AI(acac)3 1620 1592 1450 1385 1289 1190 1022 991 777 596 490 1600 1586 1416 1361 1276 1175 1016 950 771 577 425 1543 1405 939 1520 935 AI(Et)3 1480 1385 1228 1196 986 650 540 477 1440 1376 954 620 530 470 1401 921 Al(Et)2(acac) a 1592 1480 1375 1295 1193 1020 986 783 670 580 1556 1354 1289 972 775 650 560 1530 1227 946 770 620 939 700 Al(OCH(CH3)2)3 1525 1389 1261 1182 950 860 700 1374 1208 1170 835 1360 1137 1347 1125 1332 1120 'Obtained on adding excess of Al(Et)3 to Al(acac)3 solution at room temperature, according to Kroll and Naegelle [ 141 Upon increasing the amount of Al(Et)3, (Al/Co=1 5), absorptions due to Co (acac) 2 are undetectable, absorptions of Al (acac) 3 weaken, and a new set of absorptions emerges [ at 1450, 1295, 1227, 1160, 988, 951 and 905 cm-1] These results imply that the ligands of Co (acac)2 have been largely exchanged for, and that new species have been formed most likely at the expense of Al(acac)3, On basis of the reference data exhibited in Table 1, the newly emerging absorptions may account for the formation of Al (Et) 2 (acac) It has been found previously [ 14 ] , that in the presence of Al (Et) 3, Al (acac) 3 is transformed into Al (Et) (acac) 2 and at finally into Al (Et) 2 (acac) This result was confirmed in a specific reaction of Al(Et)3 with Al(acac)3 followed by IR On the other hand formation of stable Co (Et) (acac) or Co (Et) 2 species can be ruled out in view of the data reported and discussed elsewhere [ 17 ] GC analysis of gas phase products resulting from interactions between Al(Et)3 and Co (acac) 2 at room temperature and A1 /Co =1 0 and 1 5, are summarized in Table 2 It is clear that in both cases ethane is the major product (mole fraction >96%) This result implies that a major disproportionation (hydrogen-abstrac- J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalyses 93 (1994) 289-304 295 Table 2 Analysts results (% mole fraction) of the gas phase products released on mixing benzene solutions of Co(acac )Z and Al(Et)3 at room temperature and under HZ atmosphere, as a function of the Al/Co ratio and the time of mixing Al/Co 1 0 1 5 Time/min 5 60 5 60 Gas C, 01 05 03 03 C2= 0 6 - 0 1 - C2 96 2 97 9 98 7 98 4 C3= E - E - C3 01 02 E 01 -TC4 2 7 1 5 0 9 1 1 XCS - e - e tion) reaction amongst the ethyl groups, occurs according to the following equation, 2CZH5--3'CZH6+C2H4 (1) The fact that the C2H4/C2H6 ratio in the gas phase released is close to zero (Table 2) may have two conflicting implications (i) ethane is not formed via reaction (1), or (ii) it is, but the C2H4 is dissolved in benzene and/or bound to Co Quantitative calculations based on the initial concentration of Al(Et)3 and the GC analysis results, revealed that only 30% of the ethyl groups were released as C2H6 molecules, i e , one group out of three The remaining ethyl are mostly retained by Al (Et)2(acac) species, whereas the released ethyl are obtained from the reduction of cobalt This result indicates that 50-60% of the cobalt is reduced to the metallic state and that there are two types of cobalt containing species. reduced (Coo-containing) and unreduced (CoI'-containing) species On the other hand, the molar ratio of C2H4/C2H6 in the gas phase products would indicate, if reaction (1) was the actual route to C2H6 that C2H4 is largely retained in the reaction medium The solubility in benzene cannot compensate fully for the expected amount of C2H4 Therefore, the results would imply the involvement of CA in formation of the soluble cobalt complexes According to earlier reports [ 19 ] , C2H4 coordinates to metal atoms via a 8-a bonding system. The 7r-bonding becomes more important as the oxidation state of the metal becomes lower, since the metal must back-donate more electrons to olefin It has also been found [ 19,20] that most of the IR absorptions of free C2H4 undergo significant frequency shifts upon bonding to metal atoms These absorptions occur at 1623 ( v(C=C) ), 1342 ( 8s (CH2) ),1236 and 810 (p, (CH2) ), 1007 (pt (CH2) ) and 943 cm -' (p,, (CH2)) [ 19,20 ] Upon bonding to Pt, for example, these absorptions shift to 1526, 1418, 1251, 844, 730 and 1023 cm-', respectively [20] If they were occurring, all of these absorptions, except for the ones at 844 and 730 cm-', would have been completely shrouded by absorptions of Al (acac)3 296 J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 289-304 and AI (Et) 2 (acac) (Fig 1) A thorough inspection of the frequency range at 900500 cm-1 (not shown in Fig 1) revealed the display of a sharp absorption at 860 cm - t and a broad one at 850-760 cm -' in the spectrum taken following the reaction at Al/Co=1 5, notwithstanding that such an absorption might be related to vibrations of olefinic species bound to Coo atoms, and indicated the formation of Co(C2H4)x species So, IR observations accumulated in the present study can help to make concrete conclusions as to the nature of the soluble Coo complexes 3 1 2 As a function of time In order to check on the importance of the reaction duration, IR spectra were taken following the elapse of increasing periods (from 25 min to 18 h) of mixing benzene solutions of Al (Et) 3 and Co (acac) 2 (AI/ Co =1 0) at room temperature Spectra obtained at 1320-1160 cm-' are represented in Fig 2. The spectra show clearly that the chemical consequences of mixing the reagents, i.e , the appearance a 0,32 (d) 134o I3oo 1 26o 1220 1190 wAVErIUAMRs (cm-') Fig 2 IR spectra taken from a 1 I mixed solution of Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2, at room temperature Spectra of separate solutions of the precursors are inset for comparative purposes (a) Co(acac)Z, (b) t=25 mm, (c) t=18 h, (d) AI(acac)3 J Barrault et al l Journal of Molecular Catalyses 93 (1994) 289-304 297 of charactensric absorptions of Al (acac) 3, occur shortly after mixing at room temperature. The same was indicated by the GC analysis of gas phase products, which showed the completion of maximum production of C2H6 (Table 2) after the elapse of 3 mm of mixing These results indicate, m line with earlier reports [ 1 ], that reductive ligand-exchange interactions involving Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 are instantaneous 3 2 Chemical consequences of heating mixed solutions of Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 at high temperatures The synthesis of the catalytic active species m the Al(Et) 3 and Co(acac) 2 system imposes the following alterations (see Expenmental) replacement of benzene by dodecane, switching the gas atmosphere from Ar (or N2) into HZ and heating up to 180 C Therefore, expenments were designed to let IR observe chemical changes accompanying heating the catalyst precursor system to vanous mtennediate temperatures up to 180 C This was accomplished by taking spectra after hearing at the desired temperature (60, 100, 120, 160 and 180 C) for 1 to 4 h and subsequent cooling to room temperature The resulting spectra were compared with the spectra obtained pnor to heating This comparison revealed that differences appeared only at T> 100 C Therefore, Fig 3 only compares the spectra obtained before and after heating a mixture of Al (Et) 3 and Co (acac) 2 (Al /Co =1 0) at 180 C. The comparison reveals that charactensric absorptions displayed for the initial reaction products at room temperature are very much weakened on heating up to 180 C. Alternatively, several new absorptions emerged Some of these absorptions could be attnbuted to metal-C2114 (e g , at 2966, 2929, 1525, 844 and 738 cm-' [20] ) and some others to alkoxide-type species (e g , at 2955, 2916, 2910, 1525, 1465, 1369,1340,1261,1240,1177-1138, 955, 844 and 770 cm-' [21,22] ). Absorption frequencies compiled m Table 1 for Al (iPr) 3 lend support to the assignment given to the latter set of absorptions It is worth noting, however, that absorptions displayed m spectrum (b) of Fig 3 (i e , following heating at 180 C), particularly those at 1650-1500 cm-', still account for metal-acac species Nevertheless, they cannot support that these species are associated with Co (acac) 2 or Al (acac) 3 The acac species are presumably contributing to a sort of mixed Co-A1 complexes, or to mixed ligand complexes of Coo In order to identify reasons behind these remarkable, heat induced changes m the chemical composition of the reaction medium, the following expenment was carved out A 1 5 1 mixed solution of Al (Et) 3 and Al (acac) 3 was heated, under H2 at 180 C for 1 h, and then cooled to room temperature. A spectrum taken thereof is compared, m Fig 4, with that obtained from the same solution, but pnor to hearing The companson shows that Al (Et) 2 (acac) decomposed (elimination of the characteristic absorptions at 1295 and 1227 cm-') , whereas Al (acac) 3 persisted (absorptions at 1289 and 1220 cm - ' ) N hh N \o O I04 004 '~ V7 M a 0, H i 0 i03 I d IO 03 0,02 I 0,09 009 o a o 2 V r ao n N' 1650 1620 1590 1560 1530 1500 1340 1300 1260 1240 1200 1160 1120 1010 985 960 935 910 880 850 820 790 760 730 WAVENUMBERS (cm-') Fig 3 IR specO taken (at beam temperature) from a 1 1 mixed solution of Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)Z, after 60 nun and at each of the tervperatures indicated (under HZ) (a) RT, (b) 180 C J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 289-3O 0,03 t w U z 1680 1650 1620 150,0 1530 WAVENUMBEItS (cm-') ts00 1340 1300 299 0,06 a I/I~~- (-) i 1260 1220 1190 Fig 4 IR spectra exhibited by a 1 5 1 mixed solution of Al (Et)3 and Al (acac)3 (a) before and (b) after heating at 180 C for 60 nun, under Hz atmosphere GC analysis of gaseous products obtained after heating a 1 1 mixture of Al (Et)3 and Co ( acac ) Z at various temperatures up to 180 C, are given m Table 3 The results indicate that the proportion of C2H6, the mayor product at room temperature, decreases (from 97 9 to 69 3%) with temperature increase In the meantime, C1 and C3-CS products increase. These results reveal the occurrence of catalytic hydrogenolysis ( CZ -3, CI) and oligomenzarion ( CZ -4 C3-C5) m the presence of reduced Table 3 Analysis results (% mole fraction) of the gas phase products released on mixing 1 1 dodecane solutions of Co (acac)2 and Al (Et)3 under H2 atmosphere, as a function of the temperature Temperature/ C 25 120 180 Gas C, OS 193 130 CZ= - - 10 Cz 97 9 72 4 69 3 C3= - - 19 C3 02 12 28 -VC, 1 5 61 6 8 s 07 52 e After elapse of 60 min at 25 C, but 120 min at each of the higher temperatures 300 J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 289-304 cobalt species and HZ Thus, changes occurring in the gas phase composition are in line with those taking place in the liquid phase, and confirm the catalytic intervention of reduced cobalt species 3 3 Carbonylatlon and nature of metal centres 3 3 1 IR spectroscopy After mixing Al (Et) 3 and Co (acac) 2 at A1 /Co = l and room temperature, a mixture of CO and HZ (30% CO) was bubbled through the reaction medium at atmospheric pressure IR spectra were then taken as a function of time-on-stream (15-270 mm) at room temperature Subsequently, the temperature was raised up to 80 C, while the gas mixture was flowed. IR spectra were also taken as a function of time-on-stream In a second set of experiments Al (Et) 3 and Co (acac) 2 (Al/ Co =1) were mixed at room temperature under H2 atmosphere and the temperature was increased up to 180 C At each step, a (CO, H2) mixture (30% CO) was contacted with the solution and CO spectra were taken at room temperature and 80 C In the frequency range 1750-2000 cm-' corresponding to v(CO) vibrations of chemisorbed carbonyl groups [ 23,25 ] we observed significant changes (Fig 5 ) The room temperature carbonylation of the reaction mixture pretreated at room temperature results in a spectrum (a, Fig 5) displaying weak P(CO) absorptions at 1991,1950 and 1790 cm-' The former two absorptions are assignable to terminal carbonyls (M-CO) coordinated to two different types of metal atoms, whereas the latter absorption is indicative of mulricentered carbonyls ((M)x-CO) [23,25]. When the carbonylation was carried out at 80 C (spectra c), the terminal-CO absorptions intensified considerably, with the maximum being shifted to 1996 cm-' In the meantime, the multicentered carbonyls transformed into bndgingCO, ( (M)2-CO), as indicated by the high frequency shift to 1850 cm-' [23,25] Since the v(CO) of free CO molecules occurs at 2143 cm-' [23], the frequencies observed at room temperature and 80 C account for carbonyl groups coordinated to electron-rich sites with of back donating electrons to the 27r" anti-bonding orbital of the CO molecule [ 24 ] These are most likely associated with reduced cobalt (Coo) rather than with Al"' or Con Thus, the CO chemisorprion probes the existence of coordmatively unsaturated (cus) Coo atoms resulting from the reductive hgand-exchange reactions referred to above The results also indicate that these reactions are further activated at the higher temperature of 80 C. The question that may be raised at this stage is whether the CO coordination centres are associated with Coo exposed on metallic particles or contained in soluble complexed species The highest v(CO) frequency observed for the terminal-CO (at 1991 cm-') is significantly less than that reported [ 23 ] for CO terminallybound to cus sites exposed on Coo particles (at 2095-2030 cm-') This fact may imply that the CO coordination centres in the present case are more electron-rich (and hence more electron-donating) than those normally exposed on Co metal J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 289-304 301 H a o~ a N N 'r a O~ H CO; 80 C d) 180 C 0,08 O o 0,02 Y o c) RT 00 a CO. RT b) 180 C 004 a o a a) RT ,02 2050 2000 1950 1900 1850 1800 1750 WAVENUMBERS (cm-1) Fig 5 IR spectra taken (at beam temperature) from a I 1 mixed solution of Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 pretreated (1) at room temperature under hydrogen following by a (CO, HZ) adsorption at room temperature (spectrum a) or at 80 C (spectrum c), (2) at 180 C under hydrogen following a (CO, HZ) adsorption at room temperature (spectrum b) or at 80 C (spectrum d) particles This is what might be expected if the Coo is maintained atomically dispersed by electron-rich ligands such as C2H4 and alkoxides, rather than the electron-withdrawing alummium alkyls [ 9 ] Carbonylation of the hydrogen-reduced reaction mixture at 180 C led to spectra b (room temperature) and d (80 C) shown in Fig 5 Both spectra are similar m 302 J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 289-304 showing CO absorptions due to terminal and bridging carbonyls bound to complexed Coo atoms They also show that the HZ-treatment at 180 C improves considerably the amount of the Co coordination centres In contrast to the room temperature carbonylation, the carbonylation at 80 C activates two different types of coordination centres for terminal-CO ligands This is corroborated by the two absorptions at 1992 and 1960 cm-' (spectrum d, Fig. 5) These centres are most likely associated with complexed Coo atoms in different coordination symmetries. 3 4 Chromatographic analysis of gaseous products Table 4 compares GC analysis of the gaseous products formed when heating a 1 1 mixture of Al(Et) 3 and Co (acac) 2, under a (CO + HZ) atmosphere (25% CO) In comparison with the results obtained when heating the same reagents under pure HZ atmosphere (Table 3), one can find out the following CO-induced effects (i) C2H6 remains the dominant gas phase product (75-80%) at 100-160 C (Table 4) but we observed in this experiment a very important formation of C4 hydrocarbons, (u) at 180 C, the formation of C2H6 is very drastically decreased (from 80 to 18% ) to a proportion that indicates a much stronger suppression than in the absence of CO (from 98 to 69%) These results reveal that at 100-160 C, the presence of CO enhances the catalytic oligomerization to higher hydrocarbons However at 180 C, the presence of CO enhances the catalytic hydrogenolysis of C2H6 to CH4 Of course, these effects are closely related to modifications of catalytic species, Coo metal particles and soluble Coo complexed species It is obvious from Fig 5, that the presence of CO in the reducing atmosphere improves the reduction of cobalt at 180 C It also probes the availability of at least two different types of v of Coo centres, following the reduction at 180 C, as implied by the two vCO IR absorptions of terminal-CO at 1992 and 1960 cm-' (spectrum d, Fig 5) In contrast, one type of Coo centres, namely that responsible for the carbonyl absorption at 1996 cm-' (spectrum c, Fig. 5 ), is produced upon reduction at temperatures lower than 180 C Table 4 Analysts results (% mole fraction) of the gas phase products released on mixing 1 1 dodecane solutions of Co (acac)2 and Al(Et)3 under Hz atmosphere (25% CO), as a function of the temperature Temperature/ C 120 180 Gas C, 0 7 79 0 _ _ _ CZ 76 3 17 6 - _ C3 02 06 XCQ 21 6 2 7 XCS 1 1 1 2 a After elapse of 60 rmn at 25 C, but 120 nun at each of the higher temperatures J Barrault et al /Journal of Molecular Catalyses 93 (1994) 289-3O 303 It is worth mentioning that the CO-probed coordination centres are those exclusively associated with soluble Coo complexed species This should not exclude the Coo particles from playing, both actively and selectively, a role in the catalytic events observed 4. Conclusion The following conclusions can be drawn from the above results (1) At room temperature, there are reductive ligand-exchange reactions between Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 and formation of Coo particles, Coo soluble complexes, Al (acac) 3, and Al (Et) 2 (acac) in the liquid phase, C21-16 being the main gas phase product (2) The multistep transformation of reagent may be initiated through the formation of a donor-acceptor complex ( (acac)Co(acac) -+Al(Et)3) [8,9] involving the migration of an ethyl group from aluminium to cobalt [ 18 (3) The main product (C21-16) in the gas phase produced during the reaction comes from an hydrogen-abstraction mechanism (2 C2H5 -* C21-16 + C2H4) involving ethyl groups bound to alummium and cobalt, in a donor-acceptor complex as (Et) Co(acac) - Al (Et) (acac)2 (4) The presence of CO in the gas phase (HZ) when heating the reaction mixture up to 180 C, enhances the reduction of cobalt and shows that COP atoms are in different coordination symmetries within soluble complexed species (5) These Coo species exhibit different activities and selectivities towards hydrocarbon (C21-15) hydrogenolysis (to C 1) and polymerization (to C3-CS), depending on the reaction temperature Acknowledgements M I Z thanks the C N R S of France for a research associateship References [ I ] K Tama, T Saito, Y Uchida and A Misono, J Chem Soc Japan, Ind De La Cruz and N Sheppard, J Mol Structure, 224 (1990) 141 X244 94870012 0304-5102(94)87001-2 10.1016/0304-5102(94)87001-2 Infrared observation of the chemical consequences of cobalt catalyst produced in mixed solutions of Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 J. Barrault ∗ M. Blanchard A. Derouault M. Ksibi M.I. Zaki 1 Laboratoire de Catalyse, URA-CNRS 350, ESIP, 40 avenue Recteur Pineau, 86022 Poitiers Cedex, France * Corresponding author. 1 On leave from University El Minia, Egypt. Cobalt catalysts obtained from the reduction of Co(acac)2 with Al(Et)3 have been studied by infrared spectroscopy (in the selective hydrogenation of multifunctional compounds). These solids prepared in situ were in suspension in a liquid mixture containing solvent and reagent. In order to obtain information on the preparation and the composition of the catalyst we carried out an FT-IR characterization using a special device warranting sample manipulation in air-free atmosphere. At room temperature there were instantaneous and reductive ligand-exchange between Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 and formation of Co0 particles, Co0 soluble complexes and Al(Et)2(acac). The multistep process may be initiated through the formation of a donor-acceptor complex ((acac)Co(acac)→Al(Et)3). The presence of CO in the gas phase (H2) when heating the reaction mixture up to 180°C enhances the reduction of cobalt and probes Co0 in different coordination symmetries. Some of the Co0 species could be surrounded with cobalt alkoxide species and aluminium acetylacetonate. Keywords Acetylacetonate complexes Cobalt FT-IR spectroscopy Reduction Triethylaluminium References [1] K. Tamai T. Saito Y. Uchida A. Misono J. Chem. Soc. Japan 38 1965 1575 Ind. Chem. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt catalysts obtained from the reduction of Co(acac)2 with Al(Et)3 have been studied by infrared spectroscopy (in the selective hydrogenation of multifunctional compounds). These solids prepared in situ were in suspension in a liquid mixture containing solvent and reagent. In order to obtain information on the preparation and the composition of the catalyst we carried out an FT-IR characterization using a special device warranting sample manipulation in air-free atmosphere. At room temperature there were instantaneous and reductive ligand-exchange between Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2 and formation of Co0 particles, Co0 soluble complexes and Al(Et)2(acac). The multistep process may be initiated through the formation of a donor-acceptor complex ((acac)Co(acac)→Al(Et)3). The presence of CO in the gas phase (H2) when heating the reaction mixture up to 180°C enhances the reduction of cobalt and probes Co0 in different coordination symmetries. Some of the Co0 species could be surrounded with cobalt alkoxide species and aluminium acetylacetonate.
coredata.dc:title: Infrared observation of the chemical consequences of cobalt catalyst produced in mixed solutions of Al(Et)3 and Co(acac)2
